title: Protocol for measurement of calcium dysregulation in human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived dopaminergic neurons
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Calcium imaging
Timing: 2–3 h
Prepare HEPES-buffered ACSF.
Refer to materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] for buffer recipe.
Dissolve 1 mM stock solution of Fluo-4-AM with neurobasal medium to a final concentration of 2 μM (1:500 dilution).
Critical: This Fluo-4-AM working solution is prepared freshly in the hood and protected from light.
Load 1 mL of Fluo-4-AM working solution (2 μM) to human DA neurons (at differentiation day 68–75) plated on cover glasses.
Incubate neurons in a 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator for 30 min.
Remove Fluo-4-AM working solution from neurons, and wash neurons three times with HEPES-buffered ACSF.
Incubate neurons at 22°C–25°C in the dark for additional 20–25 min to allow for complete dye de-esterification.
Place neurons in a 30°C–32°C heated adaptor, and live-cell imaging is performed by inverted confocal microscope LSM880 with a 40×/1.35NA oil-immersion objective.
Critical: Perfuse imaging chamber with warm HEPES-buffered ACSF solution (30°C–32°C). High temperature (>40°C) or low temperature (<22°C) could affect the intracellular calcium level. Cells exposed to temperature range 28°C–40°C essentially maintain stable intracellular calcium level. Basically, temperature at 28°C–37°C is recommended for calcium imaging based on researcher’s own choice. In our study, we keep neurons at 30°C–32°C to avoid the temperature effect on intracellular calcium and also to maintain physiological activities of neurons.
Critical: Keep ACSF perfusion at a low rate of 1 mL/min.
Live-cell imaging is conducted with excitation wavelength of 485 nm and emission wavelength of 525 nm. Images are taken every second during the time of experiment.
Critical: The frequency of acquisition we use is 1.0 Hz. Depending on the exposure time, latency between images can be from 1 to 5 s. More than 5 s is not recommended because fast calcium transitions can be missed.

Critical: For good results, finish live-cell imaging within 2 h after transferring neurons to the microscope. Neurons after calcium imaging are not recommended for further culture.
Record basal activity for at least 5 min before applying stimuli.
Using Zen software to generate the profile of fluorescence intensity for each cell over time (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2] and Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).

Select regions of interest (ROI) by drawing the outline of cell soma. When defining ROIs, it is useful to play the movie to verify that the cells do not move during the course of experiment.
Measure fluorescence intensity values for each time point.
Transfer data to other statistical program (e.g., GraphPad Prism) for further analysis.

Ca2+ current recording
Timing: 3–4 h
Prepare external solution on the day of experiment.
Refer to materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] for buffer recipe.
Take intracellular solution out from −80°C and thaw the solution on ice.
Critical: Keep the intracellular solution on ice throughout the recording.
Prepare patch-clamp pipettes (3–5 MΩ).
Refer to materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment] for more information.

Turn on all the equipment and set the pump to perfuse external solution through the recording chamber.
Critical: The external solution is continuously bubbled with 95% O2 and 5% CO2.
Critical: The speed of external solution should be kept at 1–2 mL/min. A perfusion speed over 2 mL/min might lead to movements of the recording pipette and lifting of the cells from the coverslip.
Critical: Temperature controller and in-line solution heater are used to keep external solution at 32°C during the recording.
Transfer the coverslip with human DA neurons to the recording chamber with the cells facing up.
Fill a 1 mL syringe with 200 μL of intracellular solution, connect a 0.2 μm pore filter to the syringe and attach a micro-loader tip to the filter. Use the syringe linked to the filter and micro-loader tip to fill the patch-clamp pipette with intracellular solution.
Critical: Tap the pipette a few times to eliminate any air bubbles that might present in the tip.
Place the pipette in the pipette holder. Put the pipette tip in the bath.
Once the pipette is in the bath, apply a very light positive pressure and hold the pressure in the pipette by using a three-way valve.
Search and focus on a healthy neuron with 40× water immersion objective.
Set the amplifier to voltage-clamp mode and correct the pipette offset so the currents measured at that point are considered as 0 pA.
Move the patch-clamp pipette by multi-micromanipulator to carefully approach the selected soma. Once the pipette tip touches the cell, a very small dimple is seen in the cell’s membrane.
Release the positive pressure and apply a gentle suction to achieve gigaseal formation.

Once a gigaseal is obtained, change the voltage clamp to a negative voltage close to the expected resting membrane potential (−60 mV or −70 mV).
Rupture the membrane by applying light and short suction pulses using a syringe (or by using the “zap” function on the amplifier).
Hold the cell at −60 mV in voltage-clamp configuration. Record Ca2+ currents by stepping to various potentials from −60 mV to +50 mV for 250 ms in 10 mV increments.
Data are acquired by PatchMaster software, sampled at 10 kHz, and filtered at 2.9 kHz.
Once the recording is done, slowly and carefully detach the pipette from the neuron to let the membrane reseal.
Note: Recorded neurons are labeled with fluorescent dye and the cell type will be further validated by immunostaining.
Ca2+ currents are analyzed using Clampfit 10.5 software (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
